posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Your naked AC is 28: base 10 + 2 from DEX + 6 from 30 levels of Monk + 8 from 40 Tumble + 2 from Armor Skin = 28.
A Monk can take Armor Skin as a bonus feat, but not Epic Prowess. That leaves you with either Epic Toughness or Improved Spell Resistance.
By the time you take Epic Will, you are already immune to mental effects because you have at least 20 levels of Monk by then, so that's where you can take Epic Prowess.
Because you are taking WF Kama only to qualify for CoT, why not take it just in time, at level 9? That lets you take Blind Fight, Dodge, and Mobility earlier.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Yes, I did know about the need to waste a feat to make an unarmed CoT and have mentioned it several times in the past though can't recall exactly where.  Unfortunately, that tactic won't work for WM builds, which is probably the reason I considered the issue more related to that class than CoT.   And btw... an AD&D melee weapon is something your toon holds in its hands, not the hands themselves (though Bruce Lee would likely debate the fact).  This much fister monks share with creature weapon attacks... neither holds a weapon.  But unlike creatures, a Stoneskin buff does not allow an unarmed monk to penetrate DR +5.

But what are you trying to accomplish with DEX 14/Dodge/Mobility?  Yes, Dodge has some use as a miscellaneous AC source but can still be lost when flanked.  With this much Tumble, Mobility is totally worthless unless you are planning on wearing armor (I seriously doubt that).  This isn't a stealth build (or ED one), anyway, so DEX really doesn't factor in.  But don't believe me.  Test high Tumble with a trainer where you can spawn huge flanking mobs and see for yourself how many times Tumble triggers to avoid AoOs with a robe-wearer.

For my uses, I would rather have WIS 14 for more reliable AC, better Will saves (which happen to be your weakest, though not by much) and a better stun.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Spring Attack is the feat made useless by good tumble. The +4 AC from Mobility applies to all attacks of opportunity, not just from moving in combat. If you drink a potion during combat, Mobility will come in handy, but maybe that isn't worth it. On the other hand, what feats should he take instead?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
Anyway, I'm babbling now. But I do have a question about WIS/DEX - would you go for a 14-10 split or a 12-12? I'll do the edit once you're kind enough to advise on this one. Oh, and would dropping DEX have an impact on my ability to take Dodge and/or Mobility? Maybe Disarm or Dirty Fighting could replace one if necessary?


 
Well, you could go 12-12 in an attempt to balance saves, but with CoT boosts I hardly suspect such finessing (no pun intended) would be an advantage.  Naturally, without DEX 13, Dodge/Mobility are no longer an alternative. That's the choice I suggested for the reasons I already mentioned.  Disarm is not going be very effective without holding a large weapon (besides the AoO it triggers, that is) and Dirty Fighting.... meh... a feat that never really got off the ground for Bioware IMO.  Forces your toon to trigger a combat mode that can be just bothersome with the high APR you will be using.

Consider Called Shot. 

Besides the oft-implemented mob control feature used by archers (i.e. Leg shots), Arm shot AB penalties will stack within the long duration (4rnds) effectively increasing your toon's AC beyond any AC stacking limits that may be in effect.  The only caveat is that the target must actually have arms (or legs) to use it.  But I tend to leave Called Shot as one of the last combat feats to choose pre-epic due to the user's attack penalty, one of the higher ones.  It does take some practice to select it for the first attack in a flurry but can dominate situations that would otherwise be unmanageable. 
I appreciate that, regardless of anything else, this build could be more brutal (Half-Orc), more resilient (Dwarf), more agile (Elf), more nimble (Halfling), or more downright weird (Gnome), but I opted for the middle ground. Hope it's coming on all right.
 
I like your build methodology.  Mine works in a very similar manner. 

i.e. Build using Human first to get the largest number of feats and skillpoints and then reanalyze.  If you find you have feats/skillpoints to spare within the base framework, then begin considering racial advantages that could optimize the build's effectiveness further and start to reassemble the concept with the bias.

I like halfling but that will mean lower damage and longterm XP penalty.  Same goes for 3 of the other races you mentioned.  Dwarf will resolve the penalty issue and probably the only alternative unless the environment makes it easy to level (yes, there are still servers like this around that are designed for Level 40 toons to venture into challenging areas they would not be able to attempt at less-than-capped level).  That extra 2 ability points would be inviting to me.  I usually build without any preference as to the appearance itself so races mean nothing more than a mechanical means to achieve the optimization I seek.  No so for all players, though.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Perhaps your goal would be best-served by reading about Valerfor's Iron Fist build where many of the same issues were dissected.  You'll notice that the DEX/Dodge route was also elected in a similar build, but with Mobility conspicuously-ignored because the designer recognized it had no value, in effect wasting a full feat in a high Tumble build.  It's important to be able to separate instincts or gut feelings from quantitative evidence when you try to design for optimal effect.

I suggest you use "SkF" as an abbreviation for Skill Focus in your discussions since most will get it confused with Spell Focus which historically has been the feat associated with "SF". 

For skills requiring training (like Spellcraft), all that's needed is a single rank to open up access to the associated focus.  Cross-classing has nothing to do with SkF access.  It's a matter of whether the skill under consideration is prohibited from the class or not.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
All skills are modified by the associated ability.  Tumble has the unique distinction of boosting AC according to the alloted ranks.  So, if 40 ranks were allocated for a toon with -8 DEX, it would still get +8 Tumble AC even though the ability modifier sets the level to 39.  The 39 (modified) level would be used for all Tumble checks.  That's why a single rank in Spellcraft can benefit any class when combined with their intrinsic INT level, Fox potions and/or any complementary +INT gear...  an easy way to gain +1 saves vs. spells with almost no investment on the ledger sheet.

I'm still unclear what value all that Concentration has for a non-caster, though.  Does Aeilund really have such promiscuous MvP Taunting going on?  I can understand the use of high Conc for PvP but obviously this is a design for SP so am at a loss to understand the benefit.  What seems even more vague is Valerfor's suggested option between maxing Conc OR Listen?  Is it just the approx 40 extra skill points that need to be distributed wherever handy?  The point is: if Taunting is indeed a serious concern (like it would be in some PvP clashes), I'd max Conc and swap out PA for SkF: Conc since PA is really only useful for easy targets, chest bashing and qualifying for Great Cleave/DevCrit (which is not part of this build).  At Level 40 under mundane conditions with this build, you'd have a final Conc of 48 to counter those pesky Taunts.

But you and Empyre would know better than I how the creature AIs have been modified in these modules and the inherent value of high Concentration levels for a non-caster.

edit:  Oops.... forgot the overall opinion.  Looking well-structured and concise now.  Most all the loose ends have been addressed. Just be sure, if you should decide to publish this in the finished Level 40 section, to: 1) test it out for an hour or so in-game before posting as complete and 2) document every assignment made in consideration of environment-specific factors (like item choices you mentioned before).  It makes it so much easier for a random player to pull it up and begin re-customizing for their own SP or PW playing when the personal choices have been highlighted.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I suppose, first off, you should understand the nature of a 40 cap build.

Although the final tally reflects what combat and skill potentials are designed in, under most conditions (like optimimizing for a specific module or campaign) those totals are either never realized fully (meaning: never quite reaching Level 40 during the adventure) or are achieved at the very end.  Therefore, what matters most is the efficiency and economy that the schedule provides while playing the majority of the content.  So, with that in mind...

Small differences in final skill levels means less than regular allotments to support the journey.  Like the difference between a 33 or 37 final Spellcraft level.  What matter if the campaign has ended? This is not the case on a 40 cap server where most of the challenge takes place after Level 40 has been reached.  Quite different scenarios with equally different demands on the character progression, both in combat potential and skill mastery.  Be finicky when you figure to be playing the Level 40 toon for weeks or months.

Also, keep in mind that gear enhancements and buff items may raise a skill like Spellcraft to the next increment at different points in the build's leveling sequence.  It's hard to predict where the breakpoints will fall but experience with an environment will oft times reveal subtleties like this.  I hope this explanation hasn't been too cryptic.  It's just another way to say that the content itself will dictate when it is most important to achieve a particular skill level and even that may change depending on how XP is accrued from one toon to another (Does Aeilund employ some version of ECL adjustment? Dunno.) I suspect Empyre has drawn some conclusions about when and where levels should be in Aielund to achieve the best results so defer to his experience on that subject.

Using PA:  You'll do more damage but hit much less, especially early on when AB/BAB is so low.  So it comes down to how long you feel your toon is safe standing there missing until a good roll launches a PA.  Now, for a dexer who had the foresight to set STR at least to 13, PA could be an efficient way to cause more damage to low-AC foes.  Typically, high-AC dexers peck away little by little, so PA might afford them a way to increase damage while remaining fairly safe by virtue of their Dex AC.  A STR build has less to gain proportionately from PA since those toons can generally kill the same creatures quickly without suffering the AB penalty to do so and doesn't have enough AC to linger as long.  As a prereq to Great Cleave or DevCrit, though, PA's value changes for well-muscled toons.

Playing without "Pause" will help reduce the culture shock when you finally decide to taste on-line play, whether on a PW or with a select group of friends who set up a gaming LAN. It's good training. Additionally,  if you limit your save/reloads to only session-ending/new session-initiating actions and not to correct unwanted results, you will be emulating exactly what happens during on-line play although the death penalty varies from script to script... so you'll have to guess whether your campaign handles that the way you'd find implemented most places.  But settling for what the Fickle Finger of Fate doles out is how AD&D was designed to be played, from PnP days to present.  *When pulled over for speeding I asked the officer, innocently, whether I could please reload my last half mile on radar.  I'm sure I could roll better the second time!  Hardly glancing up, he appeared to be fumbling in his pocket for his set of handcuffs.*

Don't be intimidated about posting a complete, tested build to ECB.  The most experienced veterans among us were stumblebum noobs (in my case, eternally) at one time, though it may be too long ago for them to remember or admit!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I think most of the adverse comments about the OC stem from the somewhat-predictable plot and mechanisms devised to move the story forward (i.e. compose a shopping list of items that need to be found and returned to some NPC to gain access to another list of deliverables, and so on...).  But keep in mind, that most of these comments occurred after the expansions and some innovative CC was being released and when PWs were in their infancy.  While the OC was the one-and-only outlet for NWN... hardly a single judgemental comment was expressed.  Pretty predictable reaction IMO under the circumstances.

I still like the challenge presented in the first chapter.  It "feels" a lot like PnP to me and is well-balanced.  But the OC was never designed with prestige classes, OP feats or all those no-save uber spells in mind yet most folks who pick it up via GoG know no better.  It's hard to form a valid opinion about content that simply hasn't existed in its native form for over 10 years.  What SHOULD have happened is that the community create a "devolved" OC campaign with a hak that would remove all the improvements that were implemented through the expansions but never intended to be used within the OC framework.  Well, I have never read about any interest in rebalancing the OC and am not holding my breath in anticipation.  It's just seems such a shame that near all of the players currently playing the OC will never be exposed to the original environment, the one that translated AD&D onto the computer screen.   Today the OC has been relegated to the status of an orientation campaign, a stepping-off point for more elaborate gaming experience.

Except for the impact on the skill point total, generally-speaking, it is an advantage in a melee build, to devote early levels to fighter-type classes so that some combat hits will register.  For example, a build I posted for someone recently listed the first 3 levels as monk, cleric, rogue.  In the build, XP penalty was a huge problem due to the chosen race.  So, the result was a Level 3 toon with a BAB of 0!  In most environments, that is a recipe for failure or at least, a heck of a struggle just to progress.  That one level out of four that does not enhance BAB can get expensive because most areas scale the CR according to character level so as the enemies are getting tougher, non-fighter types will be steadlily falling behind.  Of course, there's more to combat than just statistics but still, the percentages don't lie.

The best leveling sequence for any build is always the one sculpted for a specific environment and that is only exposed through gameplay, not guessing.  Whether you decide to publish your concept as an Aielund-specific sequence or a more general scheme, I'm sure it would interest all those trying out that campaign to read about your personal adjustments and the reasoning behind them.  So start taking notes! ;)

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
You'll never see "convenience" skills allocated on ECB unless the build is skill-flushed (like some roguish ones are) or designed for a well-defined environment (in that case, a posted skill set could be construed as spoilerish information for the undoctrinated of the community).  It's up to the player to glean, adjust and prioritize a formally-published skill set level to best suit what is encountered.  In SP, skill checks can be rerolled and I have passed many important Persuade checks by simply equipping my best CHA/Persuade gear, chugging enough Eagle pots to raise the extra 2 points then saving the game for reload fully buffed.  Same goes for Appraisal (when it is scripted on store open).  Buy Clear Thought rings, maybe a Thayvian Circlet or Intellect Cap (fairly common gear) and use Fox pots before rolling the opposed merchant check.  The amount spent on the boosting gear is quickly recouped by the superior appraisals and once you get a good appraisal it will stand that way until the appraise level increases.

I have an odd relationship with stealth skills.  On the one hand, they are a cheap way to conceal for sneak attacks and death attacks.  But on the other hand, they effect movement speed.  I just finished building/testing a maxed stealth Dexer for a PW and played it through to Level 40.  I hardly ever used stealth, though.  Why?  Because it turns out that creature detection skills are so high (or presence of True Seeing skins) on the higher challenge rating level enemies who I could have benefited it most using against, that the stealth check almost always loses and I get trapped inside a mob that I would have otherwise simply pulled apart.  Good 'ol Invis pots is still my mainstay alternate to stealth and one that still allows my toon to move at full speed.  Yes, it can become expensive early on buying pots, but when potential death is factored in... a bargain.  For a dedicated sneaker, especially where HiPS has not been nerfed, though, it is a matter of economics.

As far as taunt attempts vs a high-level monk... IMO it's just misguided in PvP and ineffective in PvM.  By the time a hasted monk is perceived and the taunt action begins, the monk should have already stunned or KD'd the taunter.  They just move too fast to succumb to the short-distance taunt action.

Except for RDD, I have personally never invested a point in Lore. At times, a failed Lore check at a puzzle can be frustrating but there is almost always an alternative solution.  As for IDing purposes, in SP a single Lore pot or ID scroll will identify near everything in inventory by pausing the game (more like 5 or 6 items during on-line play if you are fast).  And again, boost your skills as you would for Appraise checks before using the ID pot/scroll.  All item values around 10K-20K can be ID'd this way with no skill investment.   Dwarves get that natural +2 to Lore to further boost the value ceiling.

I use Heal skill for the opposite reason... will neither cause an AoO nor break the combat action of my targeted ally.  For pure solo, I just break combat, displace, then heal.  I never put my toon in a situation where it must try to survive a near-death situation by emergency in-combat heal action.  If needed, first a invis pot to buy displacement time and then use the consumable in safety.  Tougher to implement vs dragons and other True Seers, but they move fairly slow so displacing is easier. Especially for a motorized monk!
